messages.content:
You are an AI assistant specialized in analyzing web projects developed using Java and the Spring Boot (Spring MVC / Spring ecosystem) framework. I need to generate an OpenAPI Specification for a web project based on its backend source code. In `src/main/java/io/github/proxyprint/kitchen/controllers/printshops/ManagerController.java`, I found that `ManagerController.listEmployees` is implemented to process HTTP requests to the path `/printshops/{printShopID}/employees`. To determine the full path with the correct prefix and the acceptable HTTP methods, I found the necessary information in other files.

I'll provide you with the contents of all related files, and your task is to determine and output:

- The full HTTP request path for the endpoint, which must begin with a forward slash (/) and have path parameters wrapped in curly braces ({}).
- Whether all HTTP methods are acceptable, this will override the results for other HTTP methods.
- Whether the HEAD method is acceptable, based on the code, not on experiential assumptions.
- Whether the POST method is acceptable, based on the code, not on experiential assumptions.
- Whether the OPTIONS method is acceptable, based on the code, not on experiential assumptions.
- Whether the TRACE method is acceptable, based on the code, not on experiential assumptions.
- Whether the GET method is acceptable, based on the code, not on experiential assumptions.
- Whether the PUT method is acceptable, based on the code, not on experiential assumptions.
- Whether the DELETE method is acceptable, based on the code, not on experiential assumptions.
- Whether the PATCH method is acceptable, based on the code, not on experiential assumptions.

You also need to provide an explanation of your results.

message.content:
- Full path: /printshops/{printShopID}/employees

- All HTTP methods acceptable: false
  (There is no @RequestMapping without a method attribute that would accept every method.)

- HEAD: false
  (No mapping explicitly for HEAD in the code. The decision is based only on explicit @RequestMapping entries.)

- POST: true
  (There is an explicit @RequestMapping(value = "/printshops/{printShopID}/employees", method = RequestMethod.POST).)

- OPTIONS: false
  (No explicit mapping for OPTIONS in the code.)

- TRACE: false
  (No explicit mapping for TRACE in the code.)

- GET: true
  (There is an explicit @RequestMapping(value = "/printshops/{printShopID}/employees", method = RequestMethod.GET).)

- PUT: true
  (There is an explicit @RequestMapping(value = "/printshops/{printShopID}/employees", method = RequestMethod.PUT).)

- DELETE: false
  (There is a DELETE mapping in this controller, but its path is /printshops/{printShopID}/employees/{employeeID} — that does not match /printshops/{printShopID}/employees exactly.)

- PATCH: false
  (No explicit mapping for PATCH in the code.)

Explanation:
The ManagerController class has no class-level @RequestMapping, so the endpoint paths are exactly the method-level values. The code contains three explicit mappings for the path "/printshops/{printShopID}/employees": one each for RequestMethod.GET, RequestMethod.POST and RequestMethod.PUT — therefore GET, POST and PUT are accepted for this exact path. Other HTTP methods are not present in any matching @RequestMapping for this path; the DELETE mapping exists but requires an additional path segment ({employeeID}), so DELETE does not apply to the exact path /printshops/{printShopID}/employees. The determination above is based only on the explicit annotations in the source code.
